Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the parent should attend
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the calendar app open, my thumb hovering over two overlapping events. My daughter’s open class at school was tomorrow evening—the one she’d been talking about for weeks, practicing her lines for the class play, asking if I’d be there in the front row. At the same time, it was the only evening my girlfriend and I had free before she left for a week-long work trip. She’d been hinting at a special dinner, just the two of us, to reconnect before her schedule swept her away.

I could already hear my daughter’s hopeful voice, “Will you come, Dad?” and see her searching for me in the crowd. But I also remembered the look in my girlfriend’s eyes last night, the way she squeezed my hand and said, “I miss us.” Both needed me, both deserved my time. My chest tightened as I imagined letting either of them down. I wanted to be the parent who never missed a moment, and the boyfriend who made her feel cherished. But I couldn’t be in two places at once. The weight of their expectations pressed on me, and I sat frozen, unable to choose.
